title: Rato Machindranath Jatra is a month-long festival in Lalitpur, Nepal. The festival begins with the bathing of the idol of Rato Machindranath and ends with the idol being returned to its shrine. The festival is celebrated to pray for rain and good harvest.
content:
The Rato Machhindra jatra, a festival celebrating the god of rain, has started. 

A chariot has been built and a statue of the deity Machhindranath has been placed on it. The chariot is being pulled from Pulchowk to Gahbahal with music. 

It will pass through Patan and stop at Jawalakhel for the bhoto jatra, a famous exhibition.

title: Swiss government will give 9.01 million Swiss francs to help with a tourism project.
content:
Switzerland is giving Nepal 9 million Swiss francs (around $9.61 million) to improve trekking tourism in Koshi Province. Around 100,000 people from 29 local areas will directly benefit from the four-year project that will have 3 main components:
- conservations of their art and culture.
- production of local products.
- promotion of sustainable tourism.

title:
Nepali Professionals in Berlin Summit
- Brings together professionals from Nepal in Berlin
- Aims to connect, network, and share experiences
- Showcases Nepalese talent and promotes professional development

content:
**Nepali Professionals' Summit in Berlin**

A summit in Berlin brought together Nepali professionals living in Germany to share knowledge and skills. The summit aimed to connect the diaspora with Nepal's development.

Discussions focused on:

* Using the diaspora's knowledge beyond remittances
* Gender equality in Nepal
* Tourism and the role of the diaspora

Sessions also covered climate change, health, and technology.

Nepal is encouraging the diaspora to contribute to its growth through programs and policy changes.
summary: The Second Nepal Professionals' Summit, held in Berlin, brought together experts to promote knowledge sharing, encourage diaspora contributions, and address themes including gender equality, tourism, and climate change, with 70 Nepali professionals in Germany participating.

title: 105 crocodiles have been released into the Rapti River.
content: 105 Gharial crocodiles from Chitwan National Park's breeding center have been released into the Rapti river. The center has released a total of 1,957 crocodiles into various rivers since 2035 BS, but their numbers haven't increased due to human activities and cross-border movement. Gharial crocodiles are critically endangered and native to Nepal and other countries.
summary: 105 Gharial crocodiles, bred at Chitwan National Park, were released into the Rapti River as part of a conservation program, despite challenges from human activities and cross-border movement.

content:
The meeting of the National Assembly was postponed twice because opposition members, led by the National Congress Party (NC), protested and refused to participate.

title: Japan and Nepal have many things in common, said Japanese Foreign Minister Kamikawa Yoko.
content:
**Similarities between Japan and Nepal:**

* Mountainous countries with 70-80% of land covered by mountains.
* Democratic nations.
* Shared history of earthquakes and mutual support in times of need.

**Japan's Support for Nepal:**

* Democracy building (election observers, legal system development).
* Earthquake relief (rescue teams, aid, reconstruction).
* Infrastructure development (roads, tunnels, electricity).
* Education, healthcare, and agriculture.

**Other Common Issues:**

* Scarcity of natural resources.
* Importance of international cooperation and freedom of navigation.

**Cooperation on Women, Peace, and Security:**

* Nepal's commitment to peacekeeping and women's participation.
* Potential for collaboration between Japan and Nepal.

**Future Goals:**

* Strengthen Japan-Nepal relationship towards the 70th anniversary of diplomatic relations in 2026.
* Support Nepal's sustainable growth and development after graduating from LDC status.
summary: Japan and Nepal share mountainous terrain, democratic values, history of earthquakes, and ongoing cooperation in infrastructure, WPS, and Nepal's graduation from LDC status by 2026.

title:
The Nepal Swadeshi Summit 2024 has released a 35-point declaration:

* Promotes national unity and prosperity
* Supports self-reliance in agriculture, industry, and technology
* Encourages foreign investment in line with national interests
* Calls for responsible tourism and environmental protection
* Emphasizes education, health, and social welfare
* Promotes cultural heritage and traditional values
content:
**Nepal's 'Make in Nepal' Summit:**

* Concluded with a plan to support local businesses and increase domestic production.
* Government pledges to use local products in government offices and explore a budget that encourages private investment.
* Plan includes revising laws and creating new ones to make it easier to start and run businesses.
* Aims to make Nepali products the first choice for consumers, ensure availability of raw materials, and differentiate taxes to support local industries.
* Calls for a special financial institution to invest in the industrial sector, a product identification portal, and improved infrastructure.
* Emphasizes the importance of government intervention to protect self-sufficient industries and encouraging the import of competitive domestic products.
* Proposes fines instead of criminal charges for industrialists accused of financial offenses, until proven guilty.
* Stresses the need for timely review of trade and investment agreements and a shared vision among political parties for economic growth.
summary: The 'Make in Nepal-Swadheshi Summit-2024' concluded with a 35-point declaration promoting local industries, domestic production, and empowering the private sector through policy and investment initiatives.

title: Nepalese runners won two titles in Malaysia.
content:
Nepali runner Mahadev Rijal won both the half marathon (today) and the Climbathon (yesterday) in Malaysia.

In the half marathon, he finished in 1:14:48 seconds, while in the Climbathon, he completed the 83-flight, 1381-step course in 3:03:58 seconds.

This is not Rijal's first win in Malaysia - he won the Tower Runner title last year and came in 8th place in the National Championship.

Rijal, who hails from Beni, Myagdi, Nepal, began running in Nepal and continued to practice while working in Malaysia.
summary: Nepali runner Mahadev Rijal achieved consecutive victories in Malaysia, winning the 21km half marathon and 21km Climbathon events with impressive timings, showcasing Nepali athleticism on a global platform.

title: Nepal defeated West Indies A in the final match to win the T20 series.
content:

West Indies scored 172 runs first, but Nepal chased the target in 18.5 overs with six wickets to spare.

Kushal Malla, Asif Sheikh, and Anil Shah made significant contributions to Nepal's victory.

Sompal Kami and Sagar Dhakal took three wickets each for Nepal in the bowling department.
summary: Nepal overcame three consecutive defeats to win the T20 series finale against West Indies 'A' by six wickets, with Kushal Malla's unbeaten 37 leading their chase of 173.

title: Dengue fever cases in Nepal's Bagmati province have exceeded 11,000.
content:
Dengue fever is common in Bagmati Province, Nepal. Over 11,000 cases have been reported since July 2023.

Dhading has the most cases (3,501), while Rasuwa has the least (2). Kathmandu has 3,000 cases, Chitwan has 1,708, and Makwanpur has 857.

One person has died from dengue in Makwanpur this year. The risk of dengue is highest in summer.

The Health Directorate is preparing a campaign to destroy mosquito larvae and prevent dengue fever.
summary: Over 11,000 dengue fever cases confirmed in Bagmati Province since July 2023, with highest cases (3,501) reported in Dhading.

title: Nepal's approach to population and development focuses on the rights of its citizens. This means ensuring access to health, education, and family planning services for all, regardless of their gender, age, or socioeconomic status.
content:
Nepal supports the right to health and development for all. The country has been working to reduce poverty, improve health, and promote gender equality since 1994.
However, challenges such as pandemics, conflicts, and climate change have slowed progress.
Nepal remains committed to advancing human rights, gender equality, and reproductive health.
Efforts will continue to reduce preventable maternal mortality, promote comprehensive sexuality education, increase youth participation in decision-making, and strengthen the national population data system.
summary: Nepal commits to a rights-based approach to population and development, emphasizing the implementation of the ICPD Programme of Action and addressing challenges like inequality, pandemics, and climate change.

title: Japan donates a community center for disaster prevention to help people prepare for and recover from natural disasters.
content: Japan gave a community center to Indrawati Rural Municipality in Nepal to help them prepare for disasters. The center will help people learn about disaster prevention, set up disaster prevention groups, and create plans to prevent landslides. The new center will also be a place for the community to gather and help the area grow and develop.
summary: Japan grants community center to Nepal's Indrawati Rural Municipality for enhanced disaster prevention.

title: Dr. Sharma, a parliamentarian, donates Rs. 2 million to a children's hospital.
content: Dr Sunil Sharma donated 2 million rupees to the Children's Hospital being built by Dr Bhagwan Koirala. The hospital aims to open specialized children's hospitals in each of Nepal's seven provinces, with a 100-bed hospital planned for Kathmandu.
summary: MP Dr Sunil Sharma provided 2 million rupees to the KIOCH, led by Dr. Bhagwan Koirala, for the construction of a specialized children's hospital in Kathmandu, part of a plan to build similar hospitals in all seven provinces.

title: Dr. Sharma, a member of Parliament, donates two million rupees to a children's hospital.
content: Dr. Sharma, a parliament member, donated 2 million rupees to help build a Children's Hospital in Kathmandu. The hospital will be run by Dr. Koirala's organization, which plans to build similar hospitals in all seven provinces of Nepal.
summary: Dr. Sunil Sharma donated two million rupees to the under-construction Children's Hospital initiated by Dr. Bhagwan Koirala, who plans to build specialized children's hospitals in all seven provinces of Nepal.

title: Children are being given vitamin A capsules and deworming tablets to improve their health.
content:
Nepal's Health Department is providing:

* Vitamin A capsules for children 6 months to 5 years old.
* Deworming tablets for children 1 to 5 years old.
* 52,000 health volunteers and 10,000 health workers are involved.
* The program runs twice a year, in April (Baishakh) and November (Kartik).
summary: The Department of Health Services in Kathmandu launched a 2-day program administering Vitamin A capsules to children under 5 and de-worming tablets to children between 1-5.

title: Businesses ask PM for help with regular flights at Gia Lai airport.
content: Business leaders in Bhairahawa have asked the Prime Minister to help them start regular flights at Gautam Buddha International Airport. The Prime Minister has promised to look into the matter.
summary: Bhairahawa private sector requests Prime Minister Dahal's assistance in establishing regular flights at Gautam Buddha International Airport, which he assures support for.

title: Fixation of ropes on Mount Everest is complete, paving the way for climbers to safely ascend the mountain.
content:
**Mount Everest Climb Open for 2024**

Seven Summit Treks has completed "rope fixing" to the summit of Mount Everest, opening the climbing season.

**Rope Fixing Team:**
* Dendi Sherpa (Team Leader)
* Tenjing Gyaljen Sherpa
* Pemba Tashi Sherpa
* Lakpa Sherpa
* Dawa Rinjee Sherpa
* Dawa Sherpa

**Climbing Permits:**

summary: Seven Summit Treks Company completed rope fixing on Everest, opening the 2024 spring climbing season for 956 climbers, including 200 women, after collecting 67 crore from permits.

title: Maha Kumbh Mela, the grand religious festival, ends today.
content: The 12-year Pindeshwar Poorna Mahakumbha Mela ended today in Chatradham, Sunsari. People from Nepal and abroad visited Chatradham, known as ancient Haridwar. Kumbha Mela is a religious festival held every 12 years in Chatradham, Allahabad, Ujjain, Nashik, and Haridwar. Hindu scriptures link the Saptakoshi River and Pindeshwardham to Kumbha Mela.
summary: The 12-year Pindeshwar Poorna Mahakumbha Mela in Barahkshetra, Sunsari, Nepal has concluded, attracting visitors from within and outside the country, linking it to the Kumbha Melas in India.

title: Government launches Innovation Fund to support growth in IT sector.
content:
Prime Minister Prachanda plans to create an "innovation fund" in the next budget to support the growth of the information technology sector.

He believes this fund will help young scientists earn money and use technology to improve the economy and society.

The government will also integrate a "Startup Program" for young entrepreneurs.

They aim to develop communication and information technology as a key factor in achieving prosperity.

The government will also work to control cybercrime through laws and policies.
summary: PM 'Prachanda' commits innovation fund establishment in next year's budget to promote IT sector development and combat cybercrimes.

title: Today is National ICT Day, celebrating the advancements in information and communications technology in the country.
content:
Today is National ICT Day, celebrated to promote technology in Nepal.

The Ministry of Communications and Information Technology is hosting a special event, with Prime Minister Prachanda as the guest of honor.

Individuals and organizations that have helped develop the ICT sector will be awarded.

The government believes that ICT can boost the economy and bring about social and economic change.

Minister of Communications and Technology, Rekha Sharma, said the government is working to make ICT accessible and affordable for all.
summary: Nepal's National ICT Day is commemorated on May 2nd, recognizing and celebrating advancements and contributions in the information and communications technology sector.

title: Politics should energize investors because government policies directly affect businesses and the economy. Smart investors stay informed about politics to make better investment decisions.
content:
President Paudel believes that for Nepal to prosper, politics should attract investors.

Nepal can become prosperous by developing its energy sector. The government should make it easier for investors, while investors should prioritize Nepal's well-being.

Nepal is politically stable and attracting more investment, which is essential for economic growth.

Nepal has transitioned from importing energy to exporting it, which is boosting the economy.

Nepal can contribute to regional economies by exporting clean energy.
summary: President Paudel emphasized the need for politics to foster investor enthusiasm, highlighting Nepal's energy potential for prosperity through government facilitation and private sector investment, while emphasizing the role of federalism and democracy in attracting domestic and foreign investment.

title:
New bill aims to regulate Artificial Intelligence (AI) and cybersecurity to ensure:

* **Transparency:** Clear explanations of how AI systems work.
* **Accountability:** Holding individuals and organizations responsible for AI's use.
* **Security:** Protecting against cyberattacks on AI systems.
content:
**New Bill: Managing IT and Cyber Security**

The bill calls for the use of AI, machine learning, blockchain, and IoT in a responsible way.

It sets up a center for researching these technologies and establishes a structure for managing IT and cyber security, including committees for coordination and rapid response.

The bill also covers electronic records, data privacy, and bans on cyberbullying and harassment.

The government will not collect personal data without informing individuals.

Government agencies must have websites and domain names must be registered.

Cyber security service providers need to be licensed.
summary: The draft IT management bill emphasizes the use of AI, ML, Blockchain, and IoT for secure and transparent cyber infrastructure, research center establishment, policy structure, and initiatives to address cyber security threats and ensure data privacy.

title: Cyber legislation is needed to resolve problems.
content: Minister Sharma emphasizes the need for cyber laws to address problems caused by misuse of technology. The government is working on draft laws and seeks suggestions from various sectors. Public awareness campaigns on cyber security are crucial. The orientation program aims to provide knowledge on protecting data and addressing cybercrime challenges, which requires an informed society.
summary: Minister Sharma emphasizes urgent need for cyber legislation to address emerging issues, seeking public input and awareness campaigns.

title: Talks are progressing with Bangladesh to export energy from India to Bangladesh. This will help Bangladesh meet its growing energy demands and strengthen the relationship between the two countries.
content: Nepal and Bangladesh agree to trade electricity soon. Nepal will sell electricity to Bangladesh during the upcoming rainy season. Final details are being finalized.
summary: Officials from Nepal and Bangladesh held positive talks on a power trade deal, with Nepal agreeing to export electricity to Bangladesh starting in the rainy season.

title:
**Yakishime: Earth Metamorphosis**

This traveling exhibition showcases Yakishime, a traditional Japanese pottery known for its unique earthy texture and black to grey hues. It explores the transformative process of clay in a traditional wood-fired kiln, revealing the beauty and diversity of this ancient ceramic art.
content:
**Japanese Ceramics Exhibition**

The Embassy of Japan is hosting an exhibition of "Yakishime" ceramics, which are traditional Japanese unglazed pottery. The exhibition will be open from May 11 to 30, from 9:30 am to 4:30 pm, at the Embassy Hall in Kathmandu.

Yakishime ceramics are made from clay and fired at high temperatures. They are unique to Japan and have been used for centuries to serve food and drink. The exhibition showcases the history and beauty of Yakishime, offering visitors a chance to experience Japanese culture and creativity.
summary: The Japan Embassy and Foundation will hold a free exhibition from May 11-30, showcasing the history and evolution of Japanese yakishime ceramics, highlighting their significance in Japanese culture.

title: Two friends celebrated their golden anniversary of friendship, having shared a close bond for half a century.
content:
**Korean Cultural Event to Celebrate 50th Anniversary with Nepal**

The Korean Embassy is hosting an event to celebrate the 50th anniversary of diplomatic ties with Nepal. Guests will enjoy:

* **Martial Art Demonstration:** K-Tigers will showcase traditional Taekwondo with a modern twist.
* **K-Dance Showcase:** People on Stage will perform exciting B-boy dance routines.
* **Friendship Ceremony:** A celebration of 50 years of friendship and cooperation between Korea and Nepal.
summary: Korea Embassy celebrates 50 years of Korean-Nepal diplomatic ties with a cultural showcase featuring Taekwondo by K-Tigers, K-Dance by People on Stage, and a friendship commemoration.

title: Actor Lokendra Lohani has passed away.
content: CP Lohani, an actor known for the movie 'Maitighar', has passed away at 86 due to Alzheimer's and pneumonia. He was also in the Ministry of Finance and Industry, and worked in film and music. He was married to Mala Sinha. His funeral will be held today at Pashupati Aryaghat.
summary: Veteran Nepali actor C.P. Lohani, known for his role in "Maitighar," passed away at age 86 due to Alzheimer's and pneumonia while undergoing treatment at Annapurna Neuro Hospital.

title: A democratic republic values morality and virtues, such as those found in religion, to guide its leaders and citizens.
content: President Paudel says that all religions, including the Federal Democratic Republic, value morality and goodness. The goal of religion is human well-being, happiness, peace, and progress. He wished Nepali Jains well and praised their contributions to Nepal through non-violence, peace, and service. Religion emphasizes ethics, truthfulness, and commitment.
summary: President Paudel emphasizes the commonality of moral values among religions, specifically during Lord Mahabir's birth anniversary, while highlighting the Jain principles of non-violence, peace, and societal progress.

title: Chaiti Chhath festival ends with devotees offering prayers to the rising sun.
content: Chhath festival, celebrated twice a year, has ended. Devotees offered "argha" to the rising sun in water bodies, wishing for peace and prosperity for their families.
summary: Chaiti Chhath festival concluded with devotees offering 'argha' to the rising sun, marking the end of their four-day fast and celebration for prosperity.

title: Socialist culture is essential for creating the foundation of a socialist society.
content: Prime Minister Dahal believes a socialist culture is essential for building a socialist society. He says the government is committed to supporting cultural institutions and promoting a sense of national unity through cultural programs.
summary: PM Dahal emphasized socialist culture as crucial for building a socialist society, promising government support for cultural institutions and promoting national unity through diverse cultural performances.

title: Probes delay budget review due to technical issues.
content:
- Nepali Congress is demanding creation of a committee to investigate corruption against Deputy Prime Minister and Home Minister Rabi Lamichhane.
- Lamichhane is opposing the investigation committee and claims the allegations are false.
- Parliament is unable to proceed due to the standoff between Congress and the ruling parties.
- The government's plans to present its policies may be delayed due to the disruption.
- Experts warn of a potential political crisis if the deadlock continues.
- The Constitution requires the government to present its annual budget by May 28.
- Congress threatens to block Parliament even if President presents policies.
- Prime Minister is meeting with party leaders to negotiate a solution.
summary: The Nepali Congress's demand for a parliamentary probe into Home Minister Rabi Lamichhane's alleged involvement in cooperative fraud threatens to delay the presentation of the government's policies and programmes.

title: Victims and activists believe that compensation alone cannot replace truth and justice. They insist on holding perpetrators accountable through the prosecution process in order to heal and prevent future conflicts.
content:
**Reparations for Insurgency Victims**

The government plans to create a plan for paying reparations to victims of the civil war. However, victims and rights groups warn that reparations should not replace other important steps towards justice, such as finding out the truth, punishing those responsible, and changing laws to prevent future violence.

Currently, some victims have received some help, but there has not been a clear plan for reparations for all. Experts say that all levels of government need to work together to provide reparations, and that the needs of victims should be considered when creating the plan.

Some people are concerned that the reparations plan may not include everyone who suffered during the war, such as those who were armed but faced human rights abuses. They also say that the plan should not just focus on money, but also include other ways of making amends, such as providing counseling or building memorials.

Experts also say that victims of sexual violence during the war have often been left out of relief programs and need to be included in the reparations plan. They also emphasize that victims need to be involved in creating the plan so that their needs are met.
summary: After 18 years since the peace process, the government is preparing a reparation action plan for victims of insurgency, while human rights advocates caution against presenting reparations as a substitute for other transitional justice aspects.

title: Cheap knockoffs of expensive makeup are becoming more common, raising concerns in the beauty industry.
content:
**Makeup Safety Concerns**

A woman in Nepal suffered an allergic reaction to eyelash glue. Research has found that some cosmetics contain harmful chemicals like lead and mercury.

Lead in lipsticks can be toxic, especially for children. It can cause health problems like learning disabilities and poisoning.

Even small amounts of lead in cosmetics can accumulate over time. Fake cosmetics often use harsh chemicals and may cause skin problems.

**Lack of Regulations in Nepal**

There are no government agencies in Nepal that regulate the use of chemicals in cosmetics.

Consumers are urged to be aware of the risks and buy from authorized retailers.

Other countries have strict laws to protect consumers from harmful cosmetics.
summary: Concerns about the safety of contaminated cosmetic products in Nepal have escalated due to high levels of lead, cadmium, and mercury, resulting in a range of health issues and prompting calls for stricter quality standards, consumer education, and regulatory measures.

title: Nepali traders are delighted with the opening of the Nepalgunj Integrated Check Post (ICP). This new facility has made it easier and faster for them to transport goods between Nepal and India.
content:
**Opening of Integrated Check Post (ICP) in Nepalgunj**

Business leaders and traders in Nepal are excited about the new ICP, which opened after 20 years of planning and 6 years of construction.

**Benefits of the ICP:**

* Makes trade easier
* Reduces illegal trade and increases government revenue
* Simplifies the process of importing and exporting through a "one-window system"
* Provides modern facilities for customs, immigration, quarantine, security, and banking
* Reduces truck queues at the border

The ICP will boost trade between Nepal and India and save time for traders. It is expected to bring benefits to the private sector and contribute to economic growth.
summary: After nearly two decades, the integrated check post (ICP) at the Nepal-India border in Nepalgunj opened, easing trade, reducing illegal activities, and increasing revenue by streamlining imports and exports through a modern facility with digital acces

title: Kritika gives Mayor Xi a successful start to his term.
content: Kritika Marasini bowled really well and helped Lalitpur Mayor's XI win their first match in the Lalitpur Mayor Women's T20 Championship by 7 wickets. She took 4 wickets, including a hat-trick. In reply, Lalitpur Mayor's XI chased down the target in 13.3 overs. A total of five teams are participating in the single-round robin event. The top two teams will play in the final.
summary: Kritika Marasini's four-wicket haul propelled Mayor XI to a seven-wicket victory in the inaugural Lalitpur Mayor Women's T20 Championship, while APF, as the most successful past champions, aim to retain their title.

title: Finance Minister's pun highlights importance of questioning and analyzing India's current situation.
content:
**Summary:**

Finance Minister Barshaman Pun said the country needs to review past mistakes and shortcomings of leaders.

The government has not spent all the money it allocated, and the private sector is struggling due to strict regulations.

The lack of investment and job opportunities is causing people to leave Nepal, including business owners.

The government needs to develop strategies to encourage investment and support the private sector.

The government has not fully utilized the investment potential of non-resident Nepalis.
summary: At the Kantipur Economic Summit, Finance Minister Pun highlighted the need for introspection, criticizing political shortcomings and government failures in coordination and investment, resulting in a slowdown in the construction industry and a reliance on remittances.

title: Mythology often reflects aspects of human life. It can provide insights into our fears, hopes, and values. By understanding mythology, we can better understand ourselves.
content:
**Bakhaamma:**

This play explores the idea that our lives may be influenced by past events and the divine. It tells the love story of Saya and Sikhum, set on a mountain where deities also fell in love.

The play showcases the Kirati Mundum, an oral tradition of storytelling that helps people understand their existence and cultural identity. The actors perform beautifully, bringing to life the Kirati community's connection to nature and their belief in the spirits of animals.

The play has some confusing moments, but overall it effectively captures the essence of the Kirati Mundum. It has been well-received by audiences, highlighting the growing enthusiasm for theater in Nepal.
summary: Mandala Theatre's "Bakhaama" explores destiny, the mystical, and love through the Kirati Mundum story of Saya and Sikhum, whose elopement parallels a deity love story, leading to societal acceptance and a celebration of Kirati cultural identity through immersive production and engaging performances.

title: Six individuals face charges for illegally buying equipment for a government printing press.
content: Six people are accused of stealing money from a government printing press deal. They bought more equipment than needed at inflated prices, causing the government to lose over 408 million rupees. One of the accused, Bikal Paudel, received a commission fee into a Singapore bank account from the equipment supplier. The anti-corruption agency wants the supplier, Max International, and its CEO charged and the money recovered.
summary: CIAA files corruption case against ex-officials for procuring inflated printing equipment, leading to government loss of over Rs400 million.

title:
**Politics and Education**

Politics influences education decisions. Governments shape policies on school funding, curriculum, and teacher training. Political ideologies can determine priorities and approaches to education.

Education, in turn, can impact politics. Informed citizens make better political decisions. Schools can foster critical thinking, debate, and understanding of current events.

Balancing these connections is important. Education should be nonpartisan, but it cannot ignore the political context. Schools must prepare students for participation in democratic society while avoiding becoming tools for political indoctrination.
content:
**Teacher and Student Political Engagement in Nepal**

**Background:**

* Political parties have expressed concern about teachers and students participating in politics.
* After the end of the Panchayat regime, educational institutions became politicized.
* Students and teachers' unions have been used by political parties to spread their ideas.

**History:**

* During the Panchayat era, students played a role in spreading multiparty ideas.
* Teachers also became politically active, but to a lesser extent.
* After the fall of the Panchayat, political parties capitalized on the existing student and teacher organizations.
* Student unions became aligned with different political parties.
* Some teachers became openly involved in political activities.

**Current Situation:**

* The Education Minister has proposed banning teachers from political involvement while working in schools.
* Different perspectives exist on how to address political influence in education.

**Importance of Considering History:**

* It is important to understand the historical context of student and teacher political engagement.
* The aspirations of students are different from those of teachers.

**Recommendations:**

* Support the minister's efforts to keep schools free from political party influence.
* Students should maintain their tradition of fighting for freedom and academic excellence.
* Teachers should avoid becoming political party cadres.
* Political parties should refrain from using students and teachers for their own purposes.
summary: Political involvement of Nepali teachers and students has been debated, with a proposal to restrict teachers engaging in political activities while holding educational positions, and a historical overview of the influence of politics in educational institutions, from the Panchayat era to the present.

title: Iran is expanding its influence eastward, seeking to increase its economic and political power in the region. It is investing in infrastructure, trade, and military alliances, aiming to become a dominant force in the Middle East and beyond.
content:
**Iran's Visits to Pakistan and Sri Lanka**

**Pakistan:**
- Iran's President Raisi visited Pakistan to improve ties and discuss regional issues, including the ongoing conflict in the Middle East.
- Pakistan and Iran have a long-standing relationship, but tensions have arisen in the past over border clashes and terrorism.
- The two countries signed agreements to increase trade and border collaboration.

**Sri Lanka:**
- Raisi's visit to Sri Lanka marked a significant step in diplomatic relations.
- Iran inaugurated infrastructure projects in Sri Lanka, including an electricity plant and irrigation system.
- Sri Lanka seeks foreign investment from Iran to boost its economy, while Iran aims to expand its presence in the Indian Ocean region.
- The two countries share a strong relationship and have cooperated in various areas, including defense and energy.

**Significance:**
- Iran's visits to Pakistan and Sri Lanka demonstrate its efforts to strengthen ties with its allies in the region.
- However, both Pakistan and Sri Lanka face economic challenges and are cautious about displeasing the US, which has imposed sanctions on Iran.
summary: Iranian President Raisi's visits to Pakistan and Sri Lanka strengthened Iran's "Look East" policy, fostering bilateral trade, project collaborations, and geopolitical support, despite ongoing tensions in the Middle East.

title:
**Reasons to Become a Teacher:**

* **Make a Difference:** Shape the lives of future generations and inspire them to reach their full potential.
* **Fulfill a Passion:** Engage in work that aligns with your interests and beliefs.
* **Impact Society:** Play a vital role in shaping a better society through education.
* **Job Security:** Teaching offers long-term employment stability.
* **Opportunities for Growth:** Advance your career through professional development and leadership roles.
* **Variety and Flexibility:** Enjoy a variety of responsibilities and flexibility in your schedule.
* **Rewarding Work:** Witness students' progress and experience the joy of shaping their minds.
content:
**Teaching is a noble profession**

Today, teaching is not as popular as before, especially at lower levels. This is because teachers are often paid less and have lower social status than people in other professions.

**Raising teachers' salaries alone won't solve the problem**

There are other issues that need to be addressed, such as corruption and lack of professionalism.

**We need to define what makes a good teacher**

Knowledge is important, but so are kindness and ethics.

**University teachers also face challenges**

They may be overworked and underappreciated.

**Teachers play a vital role in society**

They pass on both knowledge and values. It's essential to agree on what values we want them to teach.
summary: Despite the noble nature of teaching, low salaries, low social status, and a flawed system where entertainment and sports are prioritized over education, hinder individuals from choosing teaching as a career, resulting in a problematic education system that emphasizes teacher quality but lacks rigorous incentives.

title: Ruthless crime that causes immense suffering and harm to victims.
content:
Nepal's Central Investigation Bureau has issued arrest warrants for 20 people involved in a land lease scam. The accused include former officials of the Nepal Children's Organization and representatives of companies that illegally obtained land from the organization.

The leased land was illegally subleased, and the school using it used the land to obtain a loan. The arrest warrants follow a complaint filed by the organization against those involved in the scam.

This scam highlights the misuse of resources meant for disadvantaged children by private entities. The warrants are a step towards reclaiming the land and returning it to the organization and the children it serves.
summary: A land lease scam involving Nepal Children's Organization has resulted in arrest warrants issued for 20 accused, including former officials and business representatives, after an investigation into the illegal lease of 29 ropanis of land to Brihaspati Vidya Sadan school and subsequent sub-lease dealings.

title: lithuanian-presidential-hopefuls-vow-to-stand-up-to-russian-threat
content:
Lithuania's presidential election on Sunday will likely give another term to Gitanas Nauseda, who strongly supports Ukraine. 

Nauseda has 29% of voter support, while Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte follows with 14%. If no candidate wins a majority, a runoff will be held on May 26. 

Over half of Lithuanians fear a Russian attack, so increased defense spending is a key campaign issue for both Nauseda and Simonyte. The president's role includes leading the armed forces, chairing defense policy, representing Lithuania at EU and NATO summits, and vetoing laws.
summary: Lithuanians vote in a presidential election amidst security concerns, with incumbent Nauseda favored for reelection despite a runoff potential due to a lack of a majority candidate.

title: Economic advisor to the president quits.
content:
Economic expert Chiranjivi Nepal resigned after saying he didn't agree with using Nepal's new map on the 100 rupee note.

President Paudel accepted his resignation and thanked him for his work.

Nepal's new map includes areas that were previously disputed with India. The government started using it on official documents in 2020.
summary: Chiranjivi Nepal resigned as economic expert to President Paudel after controversy over his comments on Nepal's new map on new 100 rupee note.

title: Wildfires are threatening the Canadian town of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of residents.
content: A wildfire is raging southwest of Fort McMurray, Alberta, leading to an evacuation alert. The fire is out of control and windy conditions are expected to worsen the situation. In addition, the Northern Rockies Regional Municipality in British Columbia has issued an evacuation order for the town of Fort Nelson. Experts are warning that Canada is facing another severe wildfire season due to higher temperatures and El Nino weather conditions. Last year's wildfire season was the worst in Canada's history, with over 6,600 fires and 230,000 evacuations.
summary: Fort McMurray, Alberta issues evacuation alert due to an out-of-control wildfire, reminiscent of the devastating 2016 blaze that forced 90,000 evacuations and led to federal warnings of a potentially catastrophic wildfire season.

title: Elder brother died while serving in the Russian army. Younger brother has lost contact with the family.
content: Chandani Bista's husband, Birajan, joined the Russian army. Birajan's family learned of his death through an Indian man who identified him by his watch. The family held a mourning ceremony without his body. They had not heard from Birajan or his brother Nirajan for weeks. Chandani and other families of Nepali soldiers in Russia are protesting and demanding their safe return and compensation.
summary: Wife of a Nepalese soldier fighting in the Russian army, Chandani Bista, performs his final rites after learning of his death, while protests continue against the government over the lack of repatriation and support for Nepalis involved in the war.

title: Nepal will use drones to remove trash from Mount Everest, improving the iconic mountain's cleanliness and preserving its beauty.
content:
**Drones to Collect Garbage on Mount Everest**

For the first time, drones will be used to remove garbage from Mount Everest. These heavy-duty drones can carry up to 30 kilograms of trash from high-altitude camps.

**Impact on Sherpas**

If successful, drones could reduce the need for high-altitude guides who currently risk their lives carrying loads through dangerous icefalls. The Khumbu Icefall has claimed the lives of nearly 50 people since 1953.

**Other New Climbing Regulations**

* Climbers must wear tracking devices for safety.
* Base camp area restrictions to prevent overcrowding.
* Attached toilets and biodegradable bags required for waste management.
* Commercial businesses such as bars and bakeries are prohibited at base camp.
* Lights must be turned off at night to reduce pollution.
summary: Drones will transport garbage from Mount Everest, potentially reducing the risks faced by high-altitude support staff who navigate the treacherous Khumbu Icefall.

title: In Nepal, there is no clear law on child adoption. This makes it difficult for people who want to adopt children, as well as for children who are in need of a safe and loving home.
content:
**Adoption in Nepal**

Anistha Shrestha adopted a baby boy in 2017 after struggling to have children for many years.

**Legal Process for Adoption**

* Potential parents apply to court with a deed of adoption.
* Couples married for less than 10 years, single people over 45, and certain other individuals can qualify.
* Children's well-being is a priority.

**Challenges with Adoption**

* Lack of regulation and guidelines make it difficult.
* There is no dedicated committee to match children with parents.
* Parents often have to search for children themselves, which can be risky.
* Societal stigma and heteronormativity prevent LGBTQ+ couples from adopting.
* Intercountry adoptions have been banned due to concerns about trafficking and abuse.
summary: Anistha Shrestha adopted an abandoned baby in 2017, despite legal and societal barriers to adoption for both same-sex couples and domestic and inter-country adoptions in Nepal.

title: Bypoll results in Ilam show traditional parties (Nepali Congress and CPN-UML) remain strong, while Rastriya Swatantra Party faces challenges.
content:
**Election Results in Ilam-2**

Despite a new candidate from the ruling party winning the Ilam-2 by-election, the results show that the old political parties still have a strong hold.

The election also suggests that identity politics, which calls for names and policies that reflect ethnic identities, is still a significant issue in the Koshi Province, where Ilam is located.

The Rastriya Swatantra Party (RSP), a new party that made a strong showing in the last election, did not perform well in Ilam-2, showing that it needs to improve its presence in rural areas.

The election has raised questions about the RSP's ability to become a major national political force, as the old parties remain powerful in grassroots areas.
summary: CPN-UML's Suhang Nembang's victory in the Ilam-2 by-election highlights the resurgence of identity politics in Koshi Province and the challenges faced by the Rastriya Swatantra Party in establishing a national presence, despite the results reinforcing the relevance of traditional parties.

title: Nepal aims to attract LGBTQ+ tourists, a market worth billions of dollars, by promoting its welcoming environment and offering tailored experiences.
content:
Nepal hosted an LGBTIQ tourism conference to attract "pink market" tourists globally. The country has a history of recognizing LGBTIQ rights, including the first same-sex marriage in South Asia.

title:
Nepal, a small country between China and India, has a unique identity shaped by its blend of Hindu-Buddhist culture, ethnic diversity, and mountainous terrain. For centuries, it has faced challenges in navigating its relations with its powerful neighbors.

China's perception of Nepal has been influenced by its own history, culture, and geopolitical interests. Historically, China viewed Nepal as a buffer zone and tributary state. In recent times, China has sought to strengthen its ties with Nepal, seeing it as a strategic gateway to South Asia.

Nepal, on the other hand, has sought to maintain a balanced approach between China and India, while also safeguarding its own sovereignty and independence. However, the unequal power dynamics and perceived Chinese influence have raised concerns among some Nepalese about the potential for external interference and erosion of national identity.

Understanding the complexities of China-Nepal relations is crucial for both countries to build mutually beneficial partnerships while respecting each other's concerns and perspectives.

content:

**Sunkoshi Marin Project Breakthrough**

A tunnel to bring water to five dry districts in central Nepal has been completed. The tunnel will move water from the Sunkoshi River to the Marin River, which will then flow into the Bagmati River. The project will irrigate over 100,000 hectares of farmland and generate electricity.

The project is expected to cost around $87 billion and will be completed by July 2027. The breakthrough of the final point of the tunnel was completed six months ahead of schedule. The Prime Minister said that the project will help boost agricultural production and reduce the country's food deficit.
summary: The Sunkoshi Marin diversion tunnel achieved a breakthrough, six months ahead of schedule, to redirect water for irrigation and generate hydropower, aiming to alleviate drought in the central Tarai region of Nepal.

title: Government plans to check pregnant women for mental health issues to provide support and improve outcomes for both mother and baby.
content:
**Maternal Health in Nepal**

To reduce deaths during pregnancy and childbirth, the government will screen pregnant women for mental health issues.

**Reasons for Screening**

* Mental health problems are a leading cause of maternal deaths, including suicide.
* Early detection and treatment can help save lives.

**Pilot Program**

* Screening will start at Paropakar Maternity and Women's Hospital in Kathmandu.
* All pregnant women will be screened during and after pregnancy.

**Findings from Previous Study**

* 6% of maternal deaths were due to self-harm.
* 151 women died out of every 100,000 live births.

**Causes of Maternal Deaths**

* Excessive bleeding after childbirth
* Pre-eclampsia (high blood pressure during pregnancy)
* Non-obstetric complications like mental health issues

**Other Efforts to Reduce Maternal Deaths**

* Mandatory antenatal and postnatal care visits
* Free institutional delivery services
* Travel allowances for antenatal visits
* Distribution of medication to prevent bleeding

**Goal**

* Reduce maternal mortality rate to 75 per 100,000 births by 2030.
summary: Nepal's Health Ministry plans to screen pregnant women for mental health issues, citing a rise in maternal deaths due to self-harm, aiming to reduce the country's maternal mortality rate to 75 per 100,000 births.

title: Doctors and health workers receive training to detect and manage non-communicable diseases (NCDs) like heart disease, stroke, cancer, and diabetes. This training helps them provide better care to patients with these conditions.
content:

- High blood pressure
- Heart disease
- Cancer
- Diabetes
- Mental health problems

The trained workers will prescribe medicines, give advice, and refer patients to hospitals if needed. NCDs are a major health problem in Nepal, causing 71% of deaths. Smoking is a leading risk factor, followed by high blood pressure and air pollution. The government provides free medicines for some NCDs, but many people don't know they have these conditions because they are not screened.
summary: Kathmandu Health Office trains 50 health workers to screen patients for non-communicable diseases, aiming to mitigate soaring mortality rates attributed to conditions like heart disease, diabetes, and cancer.

title: Only 2% of new medicines released each year are tested in patients within 9 months.
content:
**Drug Testing in Nepal**

The Drug Administration Department has tested only 348 out of nearly 20,000 medicines in the market. This means that most medicines have not been checked for quality.

Some substandard medicines have been found and recalled. However, it's possible that there are still more substandard medicines available.

The department is responsible for ensuring the quality of medicines, but it has too few staff and its laboratory is not fully equipped.

The department collects random samples of medicines, but it takes several months to test them. This means that substandard medicines may be sold to patients before they are caught.
summary: The Department of Drug Administration tested less than 2% of registered medicines in the market, with delays in testing resulting in substandard drugs being sold to patients and the department lacking effective recall mechanisms.

* Children with asthma have trouble breathing and may wheeze.
* Asthma is treated with oxygen and medicine.
* Air pollution also causes other health problems for children, including pregnancy loss and child organ damage.
* People who live in areas with high levels of air pollution are more likely to have asthma.
* Asthma can be cured if treated early.
* If your child has trouble breathing, sleeping, or wheezing, take them to the doctor.
* Other factors like allergies and family history can also cause asthma.
* Air pollution is shortening the lives of Nepali people by around 5 years.
* Air pollution is worse in some areas of Nepal than others.
* Air pollution is deadlier than smoking and high blood pressure.
summary: Air pollution in Nepal has led to a spike in childhood asthma, with hundreds of children hospitalized due to breathing difficulties and impaired lung development, as documented by Save the Children's "Breathless Future" report, highlighting the detrimental impact on children's health, life expectancy, and various aspects of their lives.

summary: Nepal's Epidemiology and Disease Control Division prepares for a mass drug administration drive to combat lymphatic filariasis in 7 endemic districts, potentially eradicating the disease with this final campaign.

title: Nepalese cuisine is now available in New York City, thanks to new restaurants that are bringing traditional flavors to the city.
content:
**Aditya Mishra, Nepali Chef in New York**

Aditya Mishra is a chef who wants to make Nepali food famous worldwide. He started a restaurant called "The Sewing Tin" with Akhil Upad to showcase Nepali and Indian cuisine in a unique way.

Mishra believes that good food should tell stories, like the "Sewing Tin" story of immigrants getting sewing supplies instead of cookies when they arrived in New York.

He uses traditional Nepali ingredients, like kachaila (similar to French tartar), but presents them in new ways to make them accessible to everyone.

Mishra thinks that the restaurant industry in Nepal needs to be more creative and focused on creating real experiences, rather than just making money.

In New York, Mishra has faced challenges as an outsider, but he has found opportunities by staying true to his culture. He believes that chefs should be free to experiment and create dishes that they truly love.

**Mishra's Signature Dish: Confit Duck Chatamari**

**Ingredients:**

- Duck
- Rice
- Mayonnaise
- Spices
- Onions
- Garlic
- Ginger
- Radish pickle
- Scallions
- Lemon juice
- Pepper
- Vinegar

**Instructions:**

1. Cook duck in spices until tender.
2. Make garlic aioli by mashing garlic and mixing with mayonnaise and other ingredients.
3. Pickle onions in vinegar and spices.
4. Make chatamari batter and cook in duck fat.
5. Assemble by topping chatamari with shredded duck, aioli, pickled onions, and scallions.
summary: Aditya Mishra, a Nepali chef in New York City, promotes Nepali cuisine through his restaurant The Sewing Tin, showcases its unique flavors in dishes like kachaila and lamb sekuwa, and advocates for preserving the authenticity of Nepali cuisine while embracing modern culinary techniques.

* Good source of fiber

content:
**Potatoes in Nepal**

Potatoes are a very important food in Nepal, especially in the mountains. They are cheap and versatile, used in almost all dishes. Potatoes are a good source of many vitamins, minerals, and fiber. They are also a good source of carbohydrates and contain no fat, gluten, or cholesterol.

Nepal grows a lot of potatoes, around 3,410,000 tons each year. They are grown in many different parts of the country, from the plains to the mountains. Nepal also imports some potatoes and potato products.

There are many different types of potatoes, including red, white, dark, and purple. Darker potatoes have more nutrients. Potatoes can be cooked in many different ways, including boiling, frying, and roasting.

Eating potatoes can have many health benefits. They can help lower blood pressure, reduce cholesterol levels, and improve digestive health. However, it is important to limit intake of fried potato products like chips and french fries, as they can be high in calories and unhealthy fats.
summary: Potatoes are a widely consumed, versatile crop in Nepal, providing essential nutrients, with diverse types and health benefits; however, excessive consumption of fried potato products should be avoided.

* **Choline:** Supports brain function and nerve development.
* **Vitamin B12:** Essential for energy production.
* **Selenium:** Anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.
* **Lutein and zeaxanthin:** Protectors of eye health.

Regular egg consumption:

content:
**Eggs: A Superfood for Health**

Eggs are a healthy and affordable food that contains most of the nutrients our bodies need. They are a complete source of protein, which is essential for growth and repair. Eating eggs regularly can help with weight loss, lower blood pressure, and protect against infections.

Nepal produces enough eggs to meet its own needs. Eggs are available in two sizes: big and medium. Pastured eggs (from chickens that roam freely) are available but cost more. These eggs are higher in omega-3 fatty acids, which are good for heart health.

Adults can safely eat 1-2 eggs per day. Eggs are also good for pregnant women and breastfeeding mothers, as they contain choline which is important for baby's brain development.

**Benefits of Eating Eggs:**

* Weight loss
* Reduced blood pressure
* Protection against infections
* Increased mental energy
* Improved skin health
* Prevention of eye diseases
* Healthy brain development in babies
summary: Chicken eggs are nutritious and affordable, providing essential nutrients, promoting health, and contributing to Nepal's egg self-sufficiency.

title: Architecture and art come together to create something beautiful and functional.
content:
**Bara Imambara in Lucknow**

Lucknow is a vibrant city with delicious food and a rich history. It's home to Bara Imambara, a grand building built in the 1700s.

**The Entrance**

The iconic Rumi Darwaza gate welcomes you to Imambara. As you step inside, admire Asafi Mosque with its intricate designs and calm atmosphere.

**The Main Hall**

Asafi Hall is huge and impressive, with a massive arched roof supported by just bricks. The tomb of the building's builder, Asaf-ud-Daula, is located inside.

**The Labyrinth**

The Bhool Bhulaiyaa, or labyrinth, is a confusing network of passageways above the hall. Its design allows sound to echo, making it easy for guards to listen to conversations.

**The Rooftop**

From the roof, you can enjoy a panoramic view of Lucknow. It's a reminder of the building's timeless beauty and the city's changing history.

**The Stepwell**

Shahi Baoli is an underground stepwell with intricate carvings. It served as a cool refuge and natural air conditioner in the summer. Legend has it that the well's water was used to spy on people entering the building.
summary: The Bara Imambara, built in 1784, boasts a central hall without pillars, a labyrinth with echoing sounds, a royal stepwell with a 'CCTV camera' well, and a mosque with intricate Mughal calligraphy.

title: Explore the beauty of nature through guided treks and trails. Experience breathtaking landscapes, serene wilderness, and unique wildlife. Discover hidden waterfalls, lush forests, and towering mountains. Find new perspectives and create lasting memories on unforgettable adventures.
content:
**Climbing Mountains**

Climbing mountains like Everest is difficult and requires physical and mental toughness. It involves navigating slippery rocks, rivers, and bridges.

**Tips for Trekkers**

* Stay positive and believe you can do it.
* Prepare for the trek by exercising regularly, especially walking.
* Pack light but bring essentials like warm clothes, a stick, and a safety knife.
* Female trekkers should bring period supplies.
* Rest and take breaks if you get altitude sickness.
* Communicate with your fellow trekkers and guides.

**Challenges for Female Trekkers**

* They may face underestimation and doubt.
* Managing periods while trekking can be difficult.

**Becoming a Trekking Guide**

* Join a trekking association and take a guide course.
* The course covers skills like map reading and guiding techniques.
* Colleges also offer bachelor's programs in mountaineering.
summary: Everest, Annapurna, and Manaslu climbs require mental and physical fortitude, necessitating preparation, experienced guides, and essentials for navigation, while accounting for altitude sickness, injuries, and challenges faced by female trekkers.

title: Nepal won the final match against West Indies A, concluding the series with a score of 2-3.
content:
Nepal beat West Indies A by 6 wickets in the last T20 match.

Nepal's win came thanks to:

* Great batting by Aasif Sheikh, Anil Sah, and Kushal Malla.
* Strong bowling by Sagar Dhakal and Sompal Kami.

West Indies A had a decent total of 172, but Nepal chased it down with 7 balls to spare.

Kushal Malla was the star, scoring 37 runs in just 18 balls.

Despite the win, West Indies A won the 5-match series 3-2.

Rohit Paudel was named Player of the Series.

content:
**Nepal Lost to West Indies A in T20 Match**

Nepal lost to West Indies A in the fourth T20 match by 28 runs, giving West Indies an unbeatable 3-1 lead in the series. Nepal struggled to chase 210 runs, scoring only 181.

Rohit Paudel scored 82 runs for Nepal, but other batsmen struggled. West Indies A had a strong batting performance, with Andre Fletcher and Johnson Charles scoring half-centuries.

Nepal's coach selected experienced players for their upcoming World Cup campaign, but the batsmen still made mistakes. Kushal Bhurtel, who has been in poor form, got out for just one run.

Nepal had won the first T20 match but lost the second and third by wide margins. The fifth and final T20 match will be on Saturday.

Several players who performed poorly in recent matches have been dropped, including Aarif Sheikh, Bibek Yadav, and Lokesh Bam.

All-rounders Dipendra Singh Airee, Aasif Sheikh, and Kushal Malla remain in the mix.

title: India's election watchdog has been criticized for not acting against Prime Minister Narendra Modi for alleged violations of election rules. Opposition parties claim that the watchdog's inaction has allowed Modi to break the rules with impunity.
content: India’s opposition said the nation’s election commission was allowing Prime Minister Narendra Modi to continue “unchecked and brazen” violations by not taking action on opposition complaints of religious hate speech and misrepresentation.More than halfway through India’s six-week national elections, the world’s biggest, the Congress party-led opposition complained in a letter to the Election Commission of India on Friday that “no meaningful action has been taken to penalize those who are guilty in the ruling regime”.This was a “complete abdication” of the commission’s duty, it said. “As a result there has been an unchecked and brazen continuation of these violations, which are now committed with impunity and utter disregard.”The watchdog is responsible for ensuring political parties do not violate election rules against promoting division along religious, caste or linguistic lines in the multiethnic South Asian nation.In his campaign speeches, Modi, seeking a rare third consecutive term, has targeted the Congress, claiming it wants to help minority Muslims at the expense of other socially disadvantaged groups.Representatives for the commission and Modi’s Hindu-nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) did not respond to requests seeking comment.Election results in the world’s most populous nation are to be announced on June 4.The commission on Tuesday ordered social media platform X to take down a video posted by a BJP state unit that accused Congress leaders of planning to extend welfare benefits to Muslims at the cost of other disadvantaged tribal and Hindu caste groups.While not making any rulings on the complaints, the commission has sought a response from BJP chief J.P. Nadda for an April 21 speech in which Modi said the Congress planned to redistribute wealth from Hindus among Muslims, whom he called “infiltrators” and “those with many children”.The commission has also sent a notice to the Congress regarding complaints by the BJP, which says it has filed three complaints.“The delay puts a question mark on the credibility of the election commission and therefore on the election process,” said S.Y.
